question: Which building on Nevsky Prospect is known as the 'House of Books'?
explanation: Explanation: The Singer House (now known as the House of Books) is a famous Art Nouveau building originally constructed for the Singer Sewing Company.

question: What is the shortest street in St. Petersburg?
explanation: Explanation: The Second Engineering Passage is the shortest street in the city, measuring only 20 meters in length.

question: Which palace is located on Palace Square?
explanation: Explanation: The Winter Palace is one of the main landmarks of St. Petersburg and was the former residence of Russian emperors.

question: Which building is known as the 'Tower of Griffins'?
explanation: Explanation: The Wilhelm Pel House on Vasilyevsky Island is famous for the legend of griffins guarding secret knowledge.

question: Which bridge in St. Petersburg is the most frequently raised?
explanation: Explanation: Palace Bridge is the most iconic of St. Petersburgâ€™s drawbridges, raised nightly for ships to pass through.

question: Where is the famous Lion Bridge located?
explanation: Explanation: The Lion Bridge is a suspension bridge over the Griboedov Canal, decorated with lion sculptures.

question: Which street in St. Petersburg is famous for its arches?
explanation: Explanation: Bolshaya Morskaya Street is well known for its arches connecting buildings on both sides of the street.

question: Which theater is known as the 'Bolshoi Drama Theater'?
explanation: Explanation: The Bolshoi Drama Theater (BDT) named after Georgy Tovstonogov is one of Russiaâ€™s leading theaters, known for its outstanding productions.

question: Which canal crosses Nevsky Prospect?
explanation: Explanation: The Griboedov Canal crosses Nevsky Prospect near Kazan Cathedral, creating a picturesque view.

question: Which building is known as the 'Kazan Cathedral'?

options.C: Church of the Savior on Spilled Blood

explanation: Explanation: The Kazan Cathedral is one of the most recognizable landmarks on Nevsky Prospect, built in the classical style.

title: Peterhof Road â€“ The Royal Route to the Fountains
text: In 1758, Peterhof Road was built, connecting St. Petersburg to the tsarâ€™s residence. Carriages rumbled, nobles dreamed of fountains, and dust rose above the road.

title: Narva Outpost â€“ The Southern Gates of St. Petersburg
text: In the 18th century, Stachek Square was home to the Narva Outpost, a frontier of the city. Guards checked travel documents, while the vast fields of Russia stretched beyond.

title: Triumphal Narva Gate â€“ A Symbol of the 1812 Victory
text: Built between 1827 and 1834, the Narva Gate commemorates the victory over Napoleon. Architect Vasily Stasov designed the monument, crowned with bronze chariots and warriors.

title: Bloody Sunday â€“ The Tragedy of 1905
text: On January 9, 1905, workers marching to the tsar were shot down in Stachek Square. Their peaceful protest met gunfire, becoming the spark of future revolutions.

title: Putilov Plant â€“ The Heart of Industrial St. Petersburg
text: Founded in 1789, the Putilov Plant became the largest industrial center of the Russian Empire. Today, it is the Kirov Plant, a symbol of industrial heritage.

title: Pushkin House â€“ The Temple of Russian Literature
text: Founded in 1905, the Institute of Russian Literature is a sanctuary of words and ink. Manuscripts whisper stories of Russiaâ€™s literary soul. Address: Makarov Embankment, 4 â€” a haven for scholars and poets. Step inside and breathe in the dust of Pushkinâ€™s lines.

title: Cruiser Aurora â€“ The Shot That Changed History
text: The shot fired from 'Aurora' in 1917 signaled the start of the October Revolution. Its cannons woke the city, and history surged forward. Address: Petrogradskaya Embankment â€” its eternal berth. Come closer and hear the echo of that fateful blast.

title: The Siege of Leningrad â€“ 872 Days of Heroism
text: From 1941 to 1944, Leningrad withstood the iron grip of war. Cold, hunger, bombsâ€”yet its spirit never broke. Address: The entire city of St. Petersburg is a monument to their resilience. Walk its streets and honor their courage.

title: Mariinsky Theatre â€“ The Home of Russian Ballet
text: In 1860, the Mariinsky Theatre opened its doors, becoming the cradle of Russian ballet. Stars danced here, and the halls trembled with applause and music. Address: Teatralnaya Square, 1 â€” a palace of grace and art. Step inside and let the pointe shoes spin your soul.

title: Kunstkamera â€“ Peter the Greatâ€™s Cabinet of Curiosities
text: In 1714, Peter I founded Russiaâ€™s first museumâ€”the Kunstkamera of wonders. Skeletons, oddities, and mysteries of the world gathered under his stern gaze. Address: Universitetskaya Embankment, 3 â€” a house of science and strangeness. Step inside and marvel at his curiosity.

title: Nevsky Prospect â€“ The Lifeline of St. Petersburg
text: In the 1710s, Nevsky was carved out as the cityâ€™s main arteryâ€”wide and bustling. Carriages, merchants, and lights made it the face of St. Petersburg for centuries. Address: Nevsky Prospectâ€”from the Admiralty to the railway station. Walk here and feel the cityâ€™s pulse.

title: Summer Garden â€“ Peter the Greatâ€™s Green Refuge
text: In 1704, Peter I laid out the Summer Gardenâ€”a green oasis amid stone. Fountains sang, alleys beckoned, and the tsar strolled in the shade of trees. Address: Kutuzov Embankment â€” his quiet retreat. Walk here and breathe in the air of Peterâ€™s era.

title: Smolny Institute â€“ The First School for Noble Ladies
text: In 1764, Smolny became Russiaâ€™s first educational institution for womenâ€”a beacon of enlightenment. Girls studied, laughed, and dreamed under its strict dome. Address: Smolny Street, 1 â€” a cradle of knowledge. Step inside and hear echoes of their first lessons.

title: Peterhof â€“ The Tsarâ€™s Dream of Water and Glory
text: In 1710, Peter I founded Peterhofâ€”a royal paradise beyond the city. Fountains reach for the sky, palaces shine, and nature praises his will. Address: Peterhof, Razvodnaya Street â€” the imperial residence. Travel there and lose yourself in its magnificence.

title: Tsarskoye Selo â€“ The Summer Refuge of Emperors
text: Tsarskoye Selo, now the town of Pushkin, was a summer retreat of emperors, filled with luxury. Palaces and parks preserve the footsteps of Catherine the Great and her court. Address: Pushkin, Sadovaya Street â€” imperial land. Stroll here and breathe in the scent of grandeur.
